Question:
The verse says:
If everything is without essence, language is everything,
Language itself is without essence, how can it negate that essence?
If language has its own essence, the thesis established before is destroyed,
In this way there is a fault, and a superior reason should be stated again.
If you say it is like the sound of don't, this is not so,
The sound has the ability to negate sound, how can the absence of sound negate?
If you say the negation and the negated are like this, this is also not so,
In this way your thesis is self-contradictory, and not mine.
If that which is present exists, you may have a reversal;
That which is present is also non-existent, how can it be grasped and reversed?
Speaking of the four means of valid cognition such as direct perception, inference, scriptural authority, and analogy,
Direct perception, scriptural authority, and analogy can all establish.
The wise know that the Dharma taught has its own essence,
Worldly people know that there is essence, and other dharmas are also like this.
The Dharma arises from its own essence, this is what the sages say,
In the same way, non-arisen dharmas do not arise from their own essence.
If dharmas have no essence, they cannot be called non-existent;
Having its own essence is called having a name, but how can a mere name be a name?
If there is a name apart from the dharma, it does not exist in that dharma,
Saying there is a name apart from the dharma, that person can be refuted.
If dharmas have their own essence, then one can refute all dharmas,
If dharmas have no essence, then what exactly is being refuted?
Just as when there is a pot there is clay, one can refute the pot and the clay,
If something exists, then it is refuted; if nothing exists, then it is not refuted.
If a dharma has no intrinsic nature, what is there for language to refute?
If a nonexistent dharma can be refuted, then even without language, refutation is accomplished.
Just as a foolish person mistakenly takes a mirage to be water,
if you refute the mistaken grasping, the matter is also like this.
The grasped, the grasper, and the act of grasping, the refuted, the refuter, and the act of refuting,
these six kinds of meanings are all existent dharmas.
If there is no grasping, no grasped, and no grasper,
then there is no refuted, no refuter, and no act of refuting.
If there is no refuted, no refuter, and no act of refuting,
then all dharmas are established, and their intrinsic natures are also established.
Your reason is then unestablished, how can a nonexistent be a reason?
If a dharma has no reason, how can it be said to be established?
If you say that without a cause, the intrinsic nature of dharmas is reversed,
I also say that without a cause, dharmas have an intrinsic nature.
If there is a cause but no intrinsic nature, this meaning is not appropriate,
In the world, a dharma without intrinsic nature cannot be said to exist.
The previous negation is negated by the latter, in this way it is not appropriate,
If the latter negates and both are negated, in this way one knows there is an intrinsic nature.
If my words are apart from the combination of causes and conditions,
Then the meaning of emptiness is established, and dharmas have no intrinsic nature.
If the dharma of causes and conditions is empty, I now explain this meaning,
What person has causes and conditions?
Those causes and conditions have no intrinsic nature.
An illusory person in regard to an illusory person, a phantom person in regard to a phantom person,
The negation in this way is negated, and the meaning is also like this.
Words have no intrinsic nature, and what is spoken also has no intrinsic nature,
I am like this, without fault, and do not need to speak of a superior cause.
As for your statement about the sound do not, this is not my analogy,
Because I am not using this sound to be able to block that sound.
It is like if there were a man who falsely grasps at the body of a transformed woman,
And gives rise to a mind of desire, this meaning is also like this.
The same proof is not reasonable, because there is no cause in an echo,
I rely on the conventional truth, therefore I speak like this.
If one does not rely on the conventional truth, one cannot realize the ultimate truth,
If one does not realize the ultimate truth, one cannot attain the realization of nirvana.
If my standpoint had existence, then I would have fault;
Because my standpoint is devoid of things, thus I do not incur fault.
If I were to take up a different position, then I would need to use direct perception and so forth,
Taking up a different position incurs fault, if not, then how is there fault?
If the measure can establish the dharma, then it is again established by measure.
What place of measure can establish this measure?
If the measure is established apart from the measure, then your argument fails.
In this way there is a fault, and you should state a superior reason.
Just as fire is luminous, it can illuminate itself and others.
The measure is also like this, establishing both self and other.
Your words have a fault, it is not that fire illuminates itself,
Because it is not appropriate, like seeing a pot in the dark.
Moreover, if you say that fire can illuminate itself and others,
Just as fire can burn others, why does it not burn itself?
Moreover, if you say that fire can illuminate itself and others,
Then darkness should also be like this, covering both self and others.
There is no darkness in fire, where does self and other abide?
How can darkness be killed by light?
In this way, when fire is born, it illuminates at the very moment of birth.
It is not reasonable to say that fire is born and then reaches darkness.
If fire can destroy darkness without reaching it,
then fire, remaining here, should destroy all darkness.
If the means of valid cognition can establish itself without depending on what is to be measured,
then the means of valid cognition establishes itself, not depending on others to establish it.
If your means of valid cognition can be established without depending on what is to be measured,
then there would be no one using the means of valid cognition to measure phenomena.
If the object to be measured is established by depending on the means of valid cognition,
then what is to be measured is established by depending on the means of valid cognition.
If an object is not established by the means of valid cognition, then it does not depend on the means of valid cognition.ğŸ”½Why do you need the means of valid cognition to establish it?
What is the means of valid cognition establishing?
If you say that the means of valid cognition are established in dependence on the object of valid cognition,
Then the means of valid cognition and the object of valid cognition are like this, not separate.
If the means of valid cognition establishes the object of valid cognition, and if the object of valid cognition establishes the means of valid cognition,
If it is so for you, both are not established.
The means of valid cognition can establish the object of valid cognition, and the object of valid cognition can establish the means of valid cognition,
If the meaning is like this, how can they mutually establish each other?
The object of valid cognition can establish the means of valid cognition, and the means of valid cognition can establish the object of valid cognition,
If the meaning is like this, how can they mutually establish each other?ğŸ”½Is it the father who gives birth to the child,
Or is it the child who gives birth to the father?ğŸ”½Which one is the one who gives birth,
And which one is the one who is given birth to?
What is the father,
And what is the child?
You say that these two kinds, father and child, can be doubted.
The means of valid cognition is not able to establish itself, nor is it established by itself or others,
It is not established by a different measure, nor is it established without causes and conditions.
If the Dharma master says that good dharmas have their own essence,
This essence of good dharmas should be explained in parts.
If the essence of good dharmas arises from causes and conditions,
Good dharmas are the essence of others, how can they be their own essence?
If there are a few good dharmas that do not arise from causes and conditions,
If good dharmas are like this, there is no place for the practice of pure conduct.
Neither dharma nor non-dharma, nor even worldly dharmas,
If they have their own essence they are permanent, and permanence means no causes and conditions.
Good, bad, and neutral, all conditioned dharmas,
If as you say they are permanent, you have this fault.
If someone says that names exist, and language has its own essence,
That person you can challenge, saying Names and I are not real.
If this name is non-existent, then existence is also non-existent.
If you say existence and non-existence, your thesis has two faults.
If this name is existent, then non-existence is also existent.
If you say non-existence and existence, your argument has two faults.
Thus, as I said before, all dharmas are empty.
My thesis is like this, and thus I do not have any faults.
If there is a separate self-nature not included in dharmas,
you worry that I will say this, but this is not something to worry about.
If there is an existent entity that can be refuted, if emptiness can be expressed,
if there is no existent entity and no emptiness, how can refutation be established?
What is it that you are refuting?
What you are refuting is empty;
Dharmas are empty yet there is refutation, thus your argument fails.
I have nothing at all, therefore I do not refute,
In this way, your reasoning is unreasonable, and you wrongly accuse me.
The principle of your language is different, and I will now explain this meaning,
Without a dharma, one can speak, and I am therefore without fault.
You speak the analogy of the mirage to clarify the great meaning,
Listen to me, I can speak in accordance with the analogy.
If it has its own substance, it does not need to arise from causes and conditions,
If it needs causes and conditions, then it can be said to be empty.
If one grasps the true substance, who can stop it?
The same is true for the rest, therefore I am without fault.
This is the explanation without cause, the meaning has already been completed before,
The cause spoken of in the three times is spoken of equally.
If the cause in the three times is spoken of in this way equally,
In this way, the cause in the three times accords with the principle of emptiness.
If a person has faith in emptiness, that person has faith in everything;
If a person has no faith in emptiness, that person has no faith in anything.
The self-nature of emptiness is explained in terms of causes, conditions, three, one, and the middle way;
I take refuge and pay homage to that unsurpassed great wisdom!
Explanation of the first part of the VigrahavyÄvartanÄ«
The first verse of the treatise states:
If everything is without substance, language is everything;
Language itself is without substance, how can it negate that substance?
What is the meaning of this verse?

If all dharmas are due to causes and conditions, then they are causes and conditions, the combination of causes and conditions. Apart from all causes and conditions, there is no other substance. In this way, all dharmas are empty.

The sprout is not in the seed, nor in the earth, nor in water, nor in fire, nor in wind, nor in space, nor in any of the individual conditions, nor in the combination of all the conditions, nor apart from the conditions and the combination of conditions.
If it does not exist in any of these, then the sprout can be said to be without intrinsic nature.

If it is thus without any intrinsic nature, then it can be said to be empty. If all dharmas are completely empty, then there can be no language. If there is no language, then one cannot deny all dharmas.
If you think that language is not empty, while the dharmas spoken by language are all empty, this is not reasonable.
Why is it so?
Because you say that all dharmas are empty, then language is also empty.
Why is it so?
Because it does not exist in the causes.

It does not exist in the four great elements, it does not exist in each of them, it does not exist in their combination, and it does not exist in the combination or non-combination of causes and conditions.

Such language does not exist in the throat, it does not exist in the lips, tongue, teeth, palate, nose, head, etc., individually, it does not exist in their combination, and it does not exist in both places. There are only causes and conditions and the combination of causes and conditions;
If one departs from such causes and conditions and their combination, there is no other dharma.
If this is so, then all language has no intrinsic nature of its own.
If this is so and language has no intrinsic nature of its own, then all dharmas have no intrinsic nature of their own.
If this language has no intrinsic nature of its own, then there are only names to be refuted, but it cannot refute dharmas.

It is just like how without fire one cannot burn, and also like how without a knife one cannot cut, and also like how without water one cannot wash. In this way, without language, how can one refute the intrinsic natures of all dharmas?
Since it cannot block the intrinsic nature of phenomena, the mind recollecting blocks the intrinsic nature of all phenomena, but the meaning of returning is not appropriate.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If language has its own intrinsic nature, the thesis proposed earlier is destroyed,
and thus there is an error; one should further state a superior reason.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If this language has its own intrinsic nature, the thesis you proposed earlier is self-contradictory, and thus there is an error;
if so, then you should further state a superior reason.
If your intention is that language has its own intrinsic nature while other phenomena are empty, then this contradicts the statement that all phenomena are empty, and your thesis is also destroyed.
Moreover, there is another meaning: language is not separate from the category of all phenomena;
if all phenomena are completely empty, then language is also empty;
if language is empty, then it cannot block all phenomena.
If so, it would correspond to the disputes in the six kinds of non-Buddhist teachings. How is it that you do not correspond to them?
You say that all dharmas are empty, then language is also empty.
Why is it so?
Because language is also one of all dharmas.
If language is empty, then it cannot refute. If you refute that all dharmas are empty, then it does not correspond.

Moreover, if corresponding language can refute the substance of all dharmas, then the language of the emptiness of all dharmas is not empty. If it is not empty, then refuting all dharmas does not correspond.
If all dharmas are empty and language is not empty, then what does language refute?
Moreover, if this language enters into all, the analogy is not appropriate.
If that language is one of all, then all being empty, language is also empty. If language is empty, then it cannot refute.
If language is empty and all dharmas are also empty, and emptiness can block all dharmas to make them empty, then emptiness would also be a cause and condition, which is unacceptable.
Moreover, if you fear the analogy is not appropriate,
and all dharmas are empty and can act as causes and conditions, then such empty words cannot block all self-natures.
Furthermore, there is another meaning. One side has a fault, because dharmas have emptiness and also have non-emptiness.
If that has a fault, then state a superior cause again.
If one side is empty and one side is not empty, then if one says all dharmas are empty and without self-nature, the meaning is not appropriate.
Moreover, there is another meaning. A verse says:
If you say it is like the sound of 'do not,' this meaning is not so,
Because sound has the ability to block sound, how can non-sound block?
What does this verse clarify?
If your idea is that sound can stop sound, just as when a person says Don't make a sound, they themselves make a sound that can stop sound,
then in the same way, all dharmas are empty, and the word empty can stop [the idea of inherent existence].
This I now say is not appropriate.
Why is it so?
Because this sound exists, it can stop that sound;
your words do not exist, so they cannot stop the intrinsic nature of dharmas.
The meaning you establish is that words are also non-existent and dharmas are also non-existent. If you say it is like the sound don't, then this has a fault.
The verse says:
You say the stopping and what is stopped are also not so,
in the same way, your doctrine's characteristics are self-destroyed, and not mine.
What does this verse clarify?
If your idea is that stopping and what is stopped are also like this, that is not appropriate.
If you say that your words can refute all dharmas and their self-natures, that is not appropriate.
I now say that this meaning is not so.
Why is it so?
Knowing this principle, your error is not mine.
You say that all dharmas are empty, and thus your previous principle has an error, not mine.
If you say that your refutation and what is refuted are not appropriate, that is not so.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If that which is presently existent were to exist, you could have a reversal;
But since that which is presently existent is also non-existent, how can you take a reversal?
What does this verse clarify?
If all dharmas were presently existent and could be grasped, you could reverse my dharmas and make them empty, but in reality it is not so.
How do we know this?
Direct perception is included in the number of all dharmas, and thus it is also empty.
If you discriminate based on the present and the inferred,
the present and the inferred are both empty. In this way, without the present and the inferred, what can be obtained? The present and the inferred?
These two are both non-existent, so how can you refute?
You say that all dharmas are empty, but this is not so.
If you further think that by inference, analogy, or the scriptures, all dharmas can be obtained,
in this way, the intrinsic nature of all dharmas, I can refute.
This meaning is now explained.
The verse says:
The four means of valid cognition are said to be direct perception, inference, scriptures, and analogy, etc.
Direct perception, inference, and scriptures can be established, and analogy can also establish.
What does this verse clarify?
If direct perception can establish inference, scriptures, and so forth, then inference, scriptures, and so forth can all also establish.
Just as all dharmas are empty, direct perception is also empty, and inference and analogy are also empty. All dharmas established by those means of valid cognition are all empty.
Because the four kinds of valid cognition are present in all [dharmas], whatever dharma is established by inference is also established by analogy and scripture.
Those dharmas that are established are all empty. You use inference, analogy, and scripture, the three means of valid cognition, to measure all dharmas, and the object of measurement is also empty.
If it is so that the dharma cannot be obtained, the means of valid cognition and the object of valid cognition do not exist. Therefore, there is no refutation.
If it is said in this way that all dharmas are empty and without self-nature, the meaning is not appropriate.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
The wise know that the teaching of good dharmas has self-nature.
Worldly people know that there is self-nature, and other dharmas are also like this.
What is the meaning of this verse?

The samÄdhi of non-permanence lacks thirteen dharmas, and there is no place to investigate the basis.
Thus, thus are the one hundred and nineteen wholesome dharmas.

Just as good dharmas have the essence of good dharmas, and bad dharmas have the essence of bad dharmas, in the same way, indeterminate [dharmas] have the essence of indeterminate [dharmas], intrinsic indeterminacy has the essence of intrinsic indeterminacy, the desire realm has the essence of the desire realm, the form realm has the essence of the form realm, the formless realm has the essence of the formless realm, the uncontaminated has the essence of the uncontaminated, suffering, origination, cessation, and path have the essence of suffering, origination, cessation, and path, and the cultivation of concentration has the essence of the cultivation of concentration. In this way, it is seen that there are innumerable kinds of dharmas that all have their own essence.
If it is said that all dharmas are without their own essence, and that this non-essence is called emptiness, then the meaning is not consistent.
This has further meaning, as stated in the verse:
The essence of the dharma of emergence is spoken of by the sages,
In the same way, the essence of the dharma of non-emergence is the dharma of non-emergence.
What does this verse clarify?
Just as it is said that the dharma of emergence has the essence of the dharma of emergence, in the same way, the dharma of non-emergence has the essence of the dharma of non-emergence;

The self-nature of the factors of enlightenment is the factors of enlightenment, the self-nature of the factors of enlightenment is not the factors of enlightenment, the self-nature of what is not the factors of enlightenment is not the factors of enlightenment, and so on for the rest of the dharmas.

If one sees those innumerable kinds of self-natures of dharmas in this way, and yet says that all dharmas are without self-nature, and that being without self-nature is called emptiness, the meaning is not consistent.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If dharmas are without self-nature, self-nature cannot be named;
Having self-nature is having a name. How can a name be a name alone?
What does this verse clarify?
If all dharmas are without self-nature, the words expressing their lack of self-nature also do not exist.
Why is this?
Because things that exist have names, and things that do not exist are without names.
Since all dharmas have names, one should know that all dharmas have self-nature. Because dharmas have self-nature, one cannot say that all dharmas are empty.
If one says in this way that all dharmas are empty and without self-nature, the meaning is not appropriate.
The verse says:
If there is a name apart from the dharma, then in that dharma there is no name.
To say that there is a name apart from the dharma, that person can be refuted.
What does this verse clarify?

If your intention is to say that there is a dharma with a name, and there is a name apart from the dharma, in this way all dharmas are empty and without self-nature, and non-entities have no names, while entities have names.
This I will now explain.
If it is like this, what kind of person says that apart from the essence of the dharma there is a separate name?
If there is a separate name and a separate dharma, then it cannot be shown.
That which cannot be shown, in this way your mind discriminates that there are separate dharmas and a separate name, this meaning is not so.
Moreover, there is another meaning, the verse says:
If the dharma has its own essence, then one can refute all dharmas,
If dharmas are without substance, then what exactly is being refuted?
Just as when there is a pot and clay, the pot can be refuted and the clay,
If something is seen, then it is refuted; if nothing is seen, then it is not refuted.
What is the meaning of this verse?

If something exists, then it can be refuted; if it does not exist, then it cannot be refuted. Just as if there were no pot or clay, then there would be no need to refute them. If a pot exists, then it can be refuted; if a pot does not exist, then it cannot be refuted.

In the same way, if dharmas are without intrinsic nature, then there is no need to refute them. If dharmas have intrinsic nature, then they can be refuted. If they do not exist, how can they be refuted?
If all dharmas are without intrinsic nature, and one then refutes them saying All dharmas are without intrinsic nature, it is not logically consistent. What exactly are you refuting?
If there is a refuting substance, it can refute the intrinsic nature of all dharmas.
The verse says:ğŸ”½If a dharma is without intrinsic nature, what does language refute?
If a non-existent dharma can be refuted, then even without language, refutation would be established.
This verse clarifies what?
If a dharma has no essence and language also has no essence, how can one negate?
Saying that all dharmas are without self-essence?
If one negates in this way, not speaking language can also be considered negation;
If it were so, then fire is cold and water is hard, and so on, these are errors.
Moreover, there is another meaning, the verse says:
Just as a foolish person falsely takes flame for water,
If you negate the false grasping, the matter is also like this.
What does this verse clarify?
If your intention is that just as a foolish person takes flame for water, falsely grasping water in the absence of water,
A wise person would turn their mind around and say to them:
You falsely grasp water.
In this way, in all dharmas without self-essence, grasping the essence of dharmas, in order to turn around the deluded minds of those beings, it is said that all dharmas are without self-essence.
This I now explain.
The verse says:
The grasped, the grasper, the negation, the negated, the negator,
These six kinds of meanings are all existent dharmas.
What does this verse clarify?
If there are sentient beings like this, there is grasping, the grasped, and the grasper, and one can speak of false negation, the negated, etc. In this way, the six meanings are established.
If the six meanings are established and one says that all dharmas are completely empty, this meaning is not correct.
The verse says:
If there is no grasping, the grasped, or the grasper,
Then there is no negation, the negated, or the negator.
What does this verse clarify?
If your intention is to say that there is no such fault, that there is neither grasping, the grasped, nor the grasper,
If that is so, then falsely grasping and negating all dharmas without self-nature, that negation also does not exist, the negated also does not exist, and the negator also does not exist.
The verse says:
If there is no object of negation, and also no means of negation,
Then all dharmas are established, and their own-nature is also established.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If there is no negation, no object of negation, and no means of negation, then all dharmas are not negated, and all dharmas have their own-nature.
The verse says:
Your reason is not established, how can a non-existent be a reason?
If a dharma has no reason, how can it be said to be established?
What is the meaning of this verse?
If all dharmas are empty and without self-nature, then in this meaning, the reason is not established.
Why is it so?
Since all dharmas are empty and without self-nature, where is there a reason?
If a dharma has no reason, how can the emptiness of all dharmas be established by a reason?
Therefore, your statement that all dharmas are empty and without self-nature is not reasonable.
The verse says:
If you say that without a cause, the intrinsic nature of dharmas is reversed,
I also say that without a cause, dharmas have an intrinsic nature.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If your intention is that I say without a cause, dharmas have no intrinsic nature,
then like your reversal without a cause, I say dharmas with an intrinsic nature are also without a cause.
The verse says:
If there is a cause without an intrinsic nature, this meaning is not appropriate;
In the world, dharmas without an intrinsic nature cannot be said to exist.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If your intention is that I say with a cause, the cause has no intrinsic nature,
if it is like this, then the meaning of no intrinsic nature is not appropriate.
Why is it so?
All worldly dharmas without an intrinsic nature cannot be said to exist.
The verse says:
The previous negation is negated by the latter, in this way it is not appropriate,
If the negation comes later and is simultaneous, then in this way one should know that there is a substance.
What does this verse clarify?
If the negation comes first and the negated comes later, the meaning is not coherent.
Without anything negated, what is the negation negating?
If the negation comes later and the negated comes first, it is also not coherent.
The negated has already been established, so what can the negation negate?

If the two dharmas of negation and negated are simultaneous and not causal conditions, the negation is not caused by the negated, and the negated is not caused by the negation, because they all have their own substance, then one cannot say there is a negation.
Just as horns grow side by side and do not mutually cause each other - the left does not cause the right, and the right does not cause the left.
In this way, if one says that all dharmas are without self-substance, this meaning is not so.
The first part is finished.
The second part of the Treatise on the Reversal of Disputes, Part Four, is explained as follows:
As you have said, I will now answer you.
You spoke a verse, saying:
If everything is without essence, language is everything,
Language itself is without essence, how can it negate that essence?
To this verse, I now reply with a verse:
If my language is apart from the combination of causes and conditions,
Then the meaning of emptiness is established, all dharmas are without self-essence.
What is the meaning of this verse?

If that language is not in the causes, the great elements, the combination, not in the scattered, the throat, lips, tongue, teeth, palate, nose, head, etc. each have power, thus in each place, the combination is not.
If apart from such a combination of causes and conditions, there is no other dharma, for this reason, there is no self-essence.
Because of the absence of self-essence, my statement that everything is without self-essence, the meaning of emptiness is then established.
Such words are empty of self-nature, and all dharmas are empty of self-nature in the same way.
Therefore, your statement that your words are empty, so you cannot speak of emptiness is not correct.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If the dharma of causes and conditions is empty, I will now explain this meaning.
What person has causes and conditions?
Those causes and conditions are without substance.
What does this verse clarify?
You do not understand the emptiness of all dharmas and do not know the meaning of emptiness. How can you fault me?
As you say, your words are empty and words have no self-nature. Because of no self-nature, they cannot negate dharmas.
If this dharma is produced from causes and conditions, because it is produced, one can say that all dharmas are empty and can say that all are without self-nature.
For what reason is it known that dharmas produced from causes and conditions have no self-nature?
If all dharmas are produced from causes and conditions, then all dharmas are without self-nature.
If dharmas have no self-nature, then they must rely on causes and conditions. If they have self-nature, what need is there for causes and conditions?

If they are apart from causes and conditions, then there are no dharmas. If they are born from causes and conditions, then they have no self-nature. Because they have no self-nature, they can be said to be empty.
My words are also born from causes and conditions. If they are born from causes and conditions, then they have no self-nature. Because they have no self-nature, they can be said to be empty.
Because all dharmas are born from causes and conditions, their self-nature is all empty. Like carts, vases, clothes, and so forth, those dharmas each have their own causes and conditions.

The world's firewood, grass, earth-made vessels, water, honey, milk, and so forth, bringing and taking, as well as raising the palm and so on, and also the cold, hot, wind, and so forth, among the obstructions, the dharmas used for experiencing, are born from causes and conditions, and are all without self-nature.
In this way, my words are born from the combination of causes and conditions, and in this way, they can be said to have no self-nature.
If they have no self-nature, in this way, they can be said to have no self-nature accomplished.

Such empty words are accepted as useful in the world. Therefore, your statement that because of no intrinsic nature, your words are also empty, and thus you cannot refute the intrinsic nature of dharmas, is not correct.
Moreover, there is another meaning. The verse says:
An illusory person refutes an illusory person, a magical person refutes a magical person.
The meaning of the refutation and what is refuted is also like this.
What does this verse clarify?ğŸ”½It is like an illusory man, seeing various comings and goings and activities of another illusory person, refutes them;
it is like a magical man, seeing various comings and goings and activities of another magical person, refutes them.

The illusory man who is able to refute is empty;ğŸ”½if that which is able to refute the illusory man is empty, then what is refuted, the illusory man, is also empty.ğŸ”½If what is refuted is empty and the refuting of the man is also empty, the magical man who is able to refute is empty;
if that which is able to refute the magical man is empty, then what is refuted, the magical man, is also empty.
If the emptiness that is refuted is empty, then the person who refutes is also empty.
In this way, my words are empty, like an illusion, and like emptiness. Such empty words can refute the intrinsic nature of all dharmas.
Therefore, your statement that because your words are empty, you cannot refute the existence of intrinsic nature of all dharmas is not correct.
If you say that the six kinds of disputes are refuted in this way, then my words are not all dharmas.
My words are also empty, and all dharmas are also empty, not that all dharmas are completely empty.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
If words have their own intrinsic nature, then the thesis you previously established is destroyed.
In this way, there would be an error, and you should state a superior reason.
I now answer this verse, saying:
Words have no intrinsic nature, and what is spoken also has no substance.
I have no error in this way, and there is no need to state a superior reason.
What does this verse clarify?
My words arise from causes and conditions, and do not have an inherent nature.
As stated before, since an inherent nature does not arise, it can be said to be empty. In this way, it can be said that these words are empty, and all other phenomena are also empty.
Because of this emptiness, I am without fault.
If I were to say that these words are not empty while all other phenomena are empty, then I would have a fault.
I am not like this, and therefore I am without fault.
In reality, one cannot say that words are not empty while all other phenomena are empty. I do not state a superior reason for this.
If words are not empty while all other phenomena are empty, then a superior reason can be stated.
Therefore, your statement that your argument is destroyed, and you have a fault. You should state a superior reason,
is not correct.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
If you say it is like 'do not make a sound,' this reasoning is not correct.
Sound has the ability to block sound, but how can non-sound block sound?
To this verse, I now reply with a verse:
You say the sound 'do not' is not my analogy,
Because I do not use that sound to block that sound.
What is the meaning of this verse?
This is not my analogy.
How can a person who says do not make a sound himself make a sound to block sound?
Sound is not empty.
I am not like that, words are also empty, and the blocked phenomena are also empty.
Why is it so?
It is like that sound being able to turn back this sound, I am not like that;
I say like this, all phenomena are without self-nature, because of being without self-nature one can say they are empty.
Why is it so?
If the word do not turns back the absence of self-nature, then all phenomena would all accomplish self-nature, like the word do not the sound can block sound.

In this way, the statement of no intrinsic nature refutes the dharma of non-existence. If in this way one refutes intrinsic nature, then all dharmas would be established as having intrinsic nature. If there is intrinsic nature, then all dharmas are not empty.
I say the emptiness of dharmas, not non-emptiness. The analogy is like this.
The verse says:
Just as a man, deluded, grasps at the body of a magically created woman,
And gives rise to a mind of desire, this meaning is also like this.
What does this verse clarify?

Just as a magically created woman is actually empty of intrinsic nature, if a man, with regard to the body of a magically created woman, gives rise to the thought of real existence and arouses a mind of desire, he grasps at it as false;
All dharmas are also like this.

If a TathÄgata or a disciple of the TathÄgata, a Å›rÄvaka, in order to turn back the mind of false grasping of that person, or by the power of the TathÄgata's spiritual power, or by the power of the TathÄgata's disciples, the Å›rÄvakas, creates a magically created person.
Such speech is empty like an illusion, like an illusory woman who is empty of inherent nature.
The Dharma is empty in this way, and grasping at the inherent nature of the Dharma can be stopped and turned away from.
In this way, using this analogy of emptiness, one can accomplish the meaning of emptiness, and I am in accord with it, not you.
The verse says:
The same proof is not correct, because there is no cause in an echo.
I rely on the conventional truth, therefore I speak like this.
What does this verse clarify?
If you say it is like the sound mu, the reason is the same as what is being proven.
Why is it so?

Because the reason is not separate from all dharmas being without inherent nature, that sound echo does not have inherent nature, because it arises from causes and conditions it has no inherent nature.
If it has no inherent nature, your statement that sound has the ability to negate sound, that meaning is destroyed.
Moreover, what I say does not contradict conventional truth and does not abandon conventional truth. Relying on conventional truth, I can say that the essence of all dharmas is empty;
if one departs from conventional truth, dharmas cannot be spoken of.
The Buddha spoke a verse, saying:
If one does not rely on conventional truth, one cannot realize ultimate truth;
if one does not realize ultimate truth, one cannot attain the realization of nirvÄá¹‡a.
What is the meaning of this verse?
Thus, these dharmas are not empty. All dharmas are devoid of self-nature. These two are not different.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
You say that the negated and the negatee are also not so.
Thus, the characteristics of your school are self-contradictory, and not mine.
I now answer this verse, saying:
If my school existed, then I would have a fault;
because my school is devoid of things, thus I do not incur a fault.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If my standpoint exists, then there would be the characteristics of a standpoint.
If I have a standpoint and the characteristics of a standpoint, then I would incur the fault you have just stated.
But it is not like this. I have no standpoint, because all dharmas are truly tranquil and intrinsically empty. How can there be a standpoint?
In what place can the characteristics of a standpoint be found?
I have no characteristics of a standpoint. How can you fault me?
Therefore, your statement that you have the characteristics of a standpoint and incur a fault is not reasonable.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
If what is presently existent exists, then you can have a rebuttal.
But what is presently existent is also nonexistent. How can you take a rebuttal?
The four means of valid cognition, such as direct perception, inference, scriptural testimony, and analogy,
Are established by direct perception, inference, and scriptural testimony. Analogy is also able to establish.
I now answer this verse, saying:
If I accept a reversal, then I must use direct perception and so forth,
There is a fault in accepting a reversal, if not, then what is the fault?
What is the meaning of this verse?
If I am like this with a little bit of dharma, then I must use the four valid means of knowledge such as direct perception, inference, scripture, and analogy.
Moreover, there are four valid means of knowledge. If I am like this accepting a reversal, then I will have a fault.
Since I do not accept a reversal of even a little bit of dharma, if I am like this not reversing or returning, if you are like this attributing a fault to me, this is not reasonable.
If direct perception and so forth are valid means of knowledge again with valid means of knowledge established, then the valid means of knowledge would be endless.
Your meaning like this is not able to blame me.
Moreover, there is another meaning, the verse says:
If the valid means of knowledge can establish the dharma, then they are again established by valid means of knowledge,
Which place do you say the valid means of knowledge can establish this valid means of knowledge?
What is the meaning of this verse?

If you think that the means of cognition can establish things, as the means of cognition cognizes what is to be cognized, then by what means of cognition are these four means of cognition - direct perception, inference, scriptural testimony, and analogy - established?
If these four means of cognition are not established by other means of cognition, the means of cognition are not established themselves.
If what is not established itself can establish things, your doctrine is then refuted.
If the means of cognition are established by other means of cognition, the means of cognition would be infinite.
If they are infinite, then they are not established at the beginning, nor in the middle, nor at the end.
Why is this?
If the means of cognition can establish the objects to be cognized, then those means of cognition are established by other means of cognition;
because those means of cognition are established by other means of cognition, thus there is no beginning;
if there is no beginning, thus there is no middle;
if there is no middle, where is the end?
Thus, if you say that those means of cognition are established by other means of cognition, this is not reasonable.
The verse says:
If the means of cognition are established apart from the means of cognition, your argument fails.
In this way there would be an error, and a superior reason should be stated again.
What is the meaning of this verse?

If your intention is that the means of valid cognition is established apart from the means of valid cognition, and that the object to be measured is established by the means of valid cognition, if there is such a dispute that the means of valid cognition establishes what is to be measured, then you have an error.
There are things that are established by the means of valid cognition and things that are not established by the means of valid cognition. If this is so, then a superior reason should be stated.
If a superior reason is stated, then it can be known which are established by the means of valid cognition and which are not established.
You are unable to demonstrate such distinctions, and the meaning is not appropriate.
This I will now explain.
As someone says, The means of valid cognition that I speak of can establish itself and others, and speaks a verse:
Just as fire illuminates itself and others,
The means of valid cognition is also like this, establishing both itself and others.
What is the meaning of this verse?
Just as fire illuminates itself and is also able to illuminate others, the means of valid cognition is also like this, establishing itself and others.
I now answer them with a verse:
Your words have faults. Fire does not illuminate itself.
Because it is not appropriate, like seeing a pot in the dark.
What does this verse clarify?
The measure of fire illuminating itself and others is a difficulty that is not appropriate.
Why is it so?
Fire does not illuminate itself.
Like a pot in the dark that cannot be seen before it is illuminated by fire, after it is illuminated by fire one can then see it;
in the same way, if fire illuminates itself, the initial fire should be dark and only later bright. In this way one can say that fire can illuminate itself;
if the initial fire is bright, then one cannot say that fire can illuminate itself.
In this way, distinguishing fire's illumination of itself and others, the meaning is not appropriate.
Moreover, there is another meaning, expressed in a verse:
Furthermore, if you say that fire illuminates itself and others,
just as fire can burn others, why does it not burn itself?
What does this verse clarify?
If you say that just as fire illuminates itself and is also able to illuminate others, in the same way it illuminates itself and others,
in the same way it burns others and should also burn itself, but in reality we do not see such a thing.
If you say that fire illuminates itself and others, the meaning is not appropriate.
Moreover, there is another meaning. A verse says:
Moreover, if you say that fire can illuminate itself and others,
darkness should also be like this, covering both itself and others.
What does this verse clarify?
If you say that fire illuminates itself and others and can dispel darkness, why does darkness not itself and others all cover?
But in reality we do not see such a thing.
If you say that fire illuminates itself and others, the meaning is not appropriate.
Moreover, there is another meaning. A verse says:
In fire there is no darkness. Where does it dwell, itself or others?
How can darkness be killed by light? How can fire have light?
What is the meaning of this verse?
There is no darkness in fire, nor darkness in the place of fire. How can it be said that light can destroy darkness?
If there is no darkness like this in fire, where is there darkness that fire can destroy?
If there is no darkness to be destroyed, how can it illuminate itself and others?
This I will now explain.
If it is so, it is not darkness in fire, nor darkness in the place of fire. In this way, fire illuminates itself and others. When fire is born, it can destroy darkness.
In this way, there is no darkness in fire, nor darkness in the place of fire. In this way, when fire is born, it can illuminate itself and others.
This I will now explain.
The verse says:
In this way, when fire is born, it can illuminate at the moment of birth.
It is not reasonable for fire to reach darkness upon birth.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If fire, when arising, can illuminate itself and others, the meaning is not consistent.
How do we know this?
In this way, the initial fire cannot reach darkness.
How do we know this?
If it has not yet reached darkness, it cannot destroy darkness. If it does not destroy darkness, it cannot have light.
The verse says:
If fire cannot reach darkness but can destroy darkness,
then fire residing in this place should destroy all darkness.
What does this verse clarify?
If your idea is that fire, without reaching darkness, can destroy darkness, then fire residing in this place should be able to destroy all the darkness in the world.
Why is this?
Because both are not reached.
Yet in reality, such a thing is not seen.
If both are not reached, how can it only destroy the darkness in this place and not destroy the darkness in all places in the world?
If your idea is that fire, without reaching darkness, can destroy darkness, the meaning is not consistent.
There is also another meaning. The verse says:ğŸ”½If the means of cognition can establish itself
Without relying on the cognized object to be established,ğŸ”½Then the means of cognition establishes itself,
Not relying on others to establish it.
What does this verse clarify?
If your idea is that the means of cognition and the cognized object are like fire that is established, then the means of cognition establishes itself without relying on the cognized object.
Why is it so?
If it establishes itself, then it does not rely on others. If it relies on others, then it is not established by itself.
This I will now explain.
If they do not rely on each other, why do they not establish themselves?
If they rely on others, then they are not established by themselves.
This I will now explain.
If the means of cognition does not rely on the cognized object, what fault is there?
This I will now explain.
The verse says:
If the means of cognition can be established without relying on the cognized object,
Then there would be no one using the means of cognition to cognize phenomena.
What does this verse clarify?

If your intention is that the means of cognition is established without depending on the object of cognition, then there is the fault that there is no one who uses the means of cognition to cognize phenomena.
If there are people who need to use the means of cognition, then the means of cognition would exist without depending on the object of cognition.
If it is not established by depending on [the object of cognition], what fault does it incur?
Then all phenomena would not depend on the means of cognition.
If all phenomena are established without depending on the means of cognition, what fault does it incur?
[If it is established without depending on the means of cognition,] it is established by being established, and what is not yet established cannot be established, because there is no dependence.
If you further say that the means of cognition is established by depending on the object of cognition, then these four means of cognition all have establishment by dependence.
Why is it so?
If the object of cognition is not yet established, how can there be mutual dependence?
If the object of cognition is already established, there is no need for mutual dependence.

If it is not yet obtained and not yet established, then it does not depend on the object of cognition. If it is already established, it does not need to be established again, just as an object that has already been produced has no conditions for being produced again.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If the object being measured is established by relying on the measuring,
Then the object being measured is established, and only then is the measuring established.
What does this verse clarify?
If the object being measured is established by relying on the measuring, then the measuring establishes that object being measured.
Why is this?
The object being established is not established, and the measuring establishes the object being measured.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If the object is established without measuring, then it does not rely on measuring.
Why do you need to establish it by measuring?
What is that measuring establishing?
What does this verse clarify?
If your intention is that the object being measured is established without relying on that measuring, then why do you now seek to establish it by measuring?
Why is this?
What is the meaning of that measuring that is being sought?
If that object being measured is established apart from the measuring, what use is that measuring?
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If you say that measuring is established by relying on the object being measured being established,
Then the measured and the measurer are not separate.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If your idea is that because it depends on the measured object there is a measurer, fearing the previous error,
if you are like this, the measured and the measurer are not separate;
if you are like this, the measurer is the measured.
How do we know this?
The measured becomes the measurer, the measured is the measurer;
the measurer becomes the measured, the measurer and the measured are one.
The verse says:
If the measured becomes the measurer, if the measurer becomes the measured,
if you are like this, both are not established.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If your idea is that the measured becomes the measurer, because it is seen to depend on the measurer;
the measurer becomes the measured, because it is seen to depend on the measured.
If you are like this, both are not established.
Why is this?
The verse says:
The measure can establish the measured, the measured can establish the measure,
If the meaning is like this, how can they establish each other?
What does this verse clarify?

If the measure can establish the measured object, and that measured object can establish the measure, the measure itself is not yet established, and the conditions are not established, how can it establish the measured object?
Moreover, there is another meaning, the verse says:
The measured can establish the measure, the measure can establish the measured,
If the meaning is like this, how can they establish each other?
What does this verse clarify?

If the measured object can establish that measure, and that measure can establish the measured object, the measured object is not yet established, and the conditions are not established, how can it establish the measure?
The verse says:
Is it the father giving birth to the child,
or is it the child giving birth to the father?ğŸ”½Which is the one who gives birth,
which is the one who is given birth to?
What does this verse clarify?
It is like someone saying that the father can give birth to the son, and if it is like this, then the son can also give birth to the father.
Which one do you now say can give birth?
Which one is given birth to?
You say in this way that the measure is established by the measured, and the measured is established by the measure. Which one do you now say can establish?
Which one is established?
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
What is the father?
What is the son?
You say that these two kinds, father and son, are mutually suspicious.
What is the meaning of this verse?
The previously stated two kinds, namely father and son, which one is the father?
Which one is the son?
If the two characteristics of father and son are born in mutual dependence, then they are mutually suspicious. Which one is the father?
Which one is the son?
In this way, if you say that this measure and the measured, which one is the measure?
Which one is the measured?

If these two kinds can accomplish things, then one can speak of them as valid cognition. If things can be accomplished, then one can speak of them as the objects of valid cognition. Then there is no doubt as to which is the valid cognition and which is the object of valid cognition.

In this way, that which can accomplish can be called valid cognition, and that which can be accomplished can be called the object of valid cognition. Then there is no doubt as to which is the valid cognition and which is the object of valid cognition.
The verse says:
Valid cognition does not accomplish itself, nor does it accomplish itself and others,
Nor is it accomplished by a different valid cognition, nor is it accomplished without causes and conditions.
What is the meaning of this verse?

Thus, valid cognition does not accomplish itself - direct perception does not accomplish direct perception, inference does not accomplish inference, analogy does not accomplish analogy, and scriptural testimony is also like this, not accomplishing scriptural testimony;

It is not that direct perception establishes inference, analogy, and the scriptures, while inference establishes direct perception, analogy, and the scriptures, analogy establishes direct perception, inference, and the scriptures, and the scriptures establish direct perception, inference, and analogy.
It is not that there is a separate valid cognition apart from direct perception, inference, analogy, and the scriptures, which comes to establish them.

Just as valid cognition itself does not establish itself, the combination of self and other objects does not establish itself, it is not established without a cause, and it is not established by aggregation.
These causes and conditions are as explained above, twenty, thirty, or four, five, or six, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, or sixty.

If you say that because there is valid cognition, it can be said to be the object of valid cognition, and that valid cognition and the object of valid cognition prove that all dharmas have their own nature, this is not reasonable.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
The wise know that dharmas are spoken of as having their own nature,
Worldly people know that there is a nature, and other dharmas are also like this.
Emanated dharmas arise from their own nature, this is spoken of by the sages,
In this way, unemanated dharmas do not arise from the nature of unemanated dharmas.
I now answer this verse with a verse, saying:
If the dharma master speaks of dharmas as having their own nature,
This nature of good dharmas should be explained in parts.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If that dharma master considers those good dharmas to have their own nature, he should explain that good nature in parts.
This good dharma is like that good mind, the nature of the good mind.
In this way, in this way, all dharmas are not seen in this way. If it is spoken of in this way, the nature of the dharma is also not logically consistent.
Moreover, there is another meaning, expressed in a verse:
If the essence of good dharmas arises from causes and conditions,
How can good dharmas that are the essence of others have their own essence?
What is the meaning of this verse?
If the essence of good dharmas arises from the combination of causes and conditions, they are the essence of others. How can good dharmas have their own essence?
The same applies to the rest [of the dharmas].
If you say that good dharmas are the essence of good dharmas, and in the same way, unwholesome [dharmas] are the essence of unwholesome [dharmas], etc., the meaning is not coherent.
Moreover, there is another meaning. The verse says:
If there are a few good dharmas that do not arise from causes and conditions,
If good dharmas are like this, there is no place for the practice of pure conduct.
What is the meaning of this verse?

If your intention is that there are a few good dharmas that do not arise from causes and conditions, in the same way, unwholesome [dharmas] are the essence of unwholesome [dharmas], and indeterminate [dharmas] are the essence of indeterminate [dharmas];
If it were like this, there would be no place for the practice of pure conduct.
Why is it so?
If you do so, then you abandon the twelve links of dependent arising;
if you abandon the twelve links of dependent arising, then you abandon the view of the twelve links of dependent arising.
If there are no twelve links of dependent arising in this way, then one cannot see the twelve links of dependent arising;
if one does not see the twelve links of dependent arising, then one cannot see the Dharma.
The World-Honored One has said:
If a bhiká¹£u sees the twelve links of dependent arising, then he sees the Dharma.
If one does not see the Dharma, one does not abide in the holy life.
If one departs from the twelve links of dependent arising in this way, then one departs from the arising of suffering, because the twelve links of dependent arising are the arising of suffering;
if one departs from the arising of suffering, then one departs from suffering. If there is no arising, where can there be suffering?
If there is no suffering, how can there be cessation?
If there is no suffering and cessation, where can one cultivate the path leading to the cessation of suffering?

If it were so, there would be no Four Noble Truths, and if there were no Four Noble Truths, there would also be no ÅšrÄvaka path and fruits. Seeing the Four Noble Truths is thus realizing the ÅšrÄvaka path and fruits, and without the ÅšrÄvaka fruits, there would be no abiding in the holy life.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
Neither dharma nor non-dharma, and worldly dharmas are also non-existent.
If there is self-nature, it is permanent, and permanence is without causes and conditions.
What does this verse clarify?

If it were so, apart from causes and conditions coming together to give rise [to things], you would incur many faults, because dharmas and non-dharmas would not be possible, and all worldly dharmas would be unobtainable.
Why is it so?
Because all dharmas arise from causes and conditions coming together. All dharmas arise from causes and conditions coming together;
if there were no arising from causes and conditions coming together, then all dharmas would be unobtainable.
Moreover, its own essence does not arise from the combination of causes and conditions. If there are no causes and conditions, it is a permanent dharma.
Why is it so?
Because a dharma without causes and conditions is permanent.
If it is so, there is no abiding in pure conduct.
Moreover, your teaching has its own faults.
Why is it so?
The World-Honored One said, All conditioned things are impermanent.
What is their own essence that is all impermanent?
The verse says:
Good, bad, and neutral, all conditioned dharmas,
If you say they are permanent, you have such faults.
What does this verse clarify?
If it is said that good dharmas have the essence of dharmas, bad and neutral are also said to be so.
If it is so, you say that all conditioned dharmas are permanent.
Why is it so?
If dharmas have no causes, there is no arising, abiding, or ceasing.
If non-arising, abiding, and ceasing are not conditioned phenomena, then all phenomena are unconditioned.
If you say that all phenomena such as good are all with self-nature, then all phenomena are all not empty, and the meaning is not appropriate.
Moreover, you speak a verse, saying:
If phenomena are without self-nature, self-nature cannot be named;
Having self-nature is named, how is only the name named?
This verse I now answer, saying:
If a person says that the name has self-nature, the words have self-nature,
That person you can criticize, saying 'The name is not real for me.'
What is the meaning of this verse?
If someone says that the name has self-nature, that person is like this, you can then criticize.
That person says, Having self-nature is named, without self-nature is not named.
I do not say like this, that having a name is having self-nature.
How do I know this?
All dharmas are without self-nature. If they are without self-nature, they can be said to be empty. If they are empty, they cannot be said to be real.
If you say there is a name and self-nature, it is not logically consistent.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
If this name is non-existent, then existence is also non-existent.
If you say there is and say there is not, your thesis has two faults.
If this name is existent, then non-existence is also existent.
If you say there is not and say there is, your argument has two faults.
What does this verse clarify?ğŸ”½If this name is non-existent, this is a fault in the thesis;
if it is existent, this is a fault in the argument.
Our school is not like this.
Things that exist have names, things that do not exist have no names.
In this way, if dharmas have self-nature, it is not logically consistent.
Moreover, there is another meaning, as stated in the verse:
As I have said before, all dharmas are empty.
then one cannot have faults.
What does this verse clarify?
I have previously said that all dharmas are empty and also called empty.
You grasp the name empty and say something.
If all dharmas are without self-nature, the name is also without substance. I say this, the doctrinal standpoint is without fault, because I do not say the name has self-nature.
Moreover, you say in verse:
If apart from dharmas there is a name, not in the dharmas,
Saying there is a name apart from dharmas, that person can be criticized.
I now answer this verse, saying:
If there is a separate self-nature, not in the dharmas,
You worry that I say this, but this is not necessary to worry about.
What does this verse clarify?
They do not need to worry about your falsely criticizing me. I do not block the self-nature of all dharmas. I do not grasp apart from dharmas any separate thing.
Who grasps at dharmas, that person needs to worry.
I do not grasp at dharmas, therefore I do not obstruct dharmas, how can there be a fault?
If I grasped at dharmas having self-nature, then it would be reasonable to criticize me;
I am not like this, your criticism is far-fetched and completely unreasonable.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
If dharmas have self-nature, then one can obstruct all dharmas,
Dharmas have no self-nature, what exactly is being obstructed?
Just as a pot has clay, one can obstruct the pot and clay,
Seeing that there is an object, one obstructs it, seeing that there is no object, one does not obstruct.
I now answer this verse, saying:
If there is a substance that can be obstructed, if emptiness can be expressed as accomplished,
If there is no substance and no emptiness, how can obstruction be accomplished?
What is the meaning of this verse?
If dharmas exist, then dharmas can be obstructed. If they do not exist, then they cannot be obstructed.
You criticize me, saying that all dharmas are without self-nature. It is truly as you say that all dharmas are without self-nature.
How do we know this?
Because you refute the dharmas as being without self-nature.
If you refute the dharmas as being without self-nature, you can say that all dharmas are empty.
The verse says:
What are you refuting?
What you refute is empty;
The dharma is empty, yet there is refutation. Thus your argument fails.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If all dharmas are refuted as having self-nature, if they are without self-nature, they can be said to be empty, and that emptiness is also empty.
Therefore your statement that an existent thing can be refuted, but a non-existent thing cannot be refuted, is not logically consistent.
Moreover, there is another meaning, expressed in the verse:
I have nothing at all, therefore I do not refute.
Thus you have no reason, yet you falsely criticize me.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If I had even a little thing to block, you could fault me.
I have nothing to block, and thus having nothing, I have nothing to block. Thus, all dharmas are empty.
Thus, having nothing to block and nothing to be blocked, therefore your earlier objection, What is being blocked? is an unreasonable and groundless objection against me.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
If a dharma has no intrinsic nature, what does language block?
If a dharma can be blocked without being spoken, non-language can also accomplish blocking.
I now answer this verse, saying:
Your language and dharma are separate, this meaning I now explain.
Without a dharma, language can be spoken, and thus I have no fault.
What is the meaning of this verse?
If you say that even without words there is still negation, then all dharmas are without self-nature, and the words all dharmas are without self-nature do not make them without self-nature.
I now answer this: if the words all dharmas are without self-nature are spoken, these words do not make dharmas without self-nature;
Moreover, there is another meaning:
Knowing the absence of self-nature of dharmas with the absence of self-nature of dharmas, knowing the presence of self-nature of dharmas with the presence of self-nature of dharmas.
For example, there really is no Devadatta in a house. Someone asks, Is there Devadatta? The answerer says yes. Another says no. The one who says no says:
He cannot make Devadatta non-existent in the house, but he just knows that the house is empty and has no Devadatta.

In the same way, if it is said that all dharmas are without self-nature, these words cannot make all dharmas without self-nature, but they just know that the self-nature of dharmas is without self-nature.

If you say, If there is no entity, then one cannot say that dharmas have no intrinsic nature, because without words one cannot establish that dharmas have no intrinsic nature, the meaning is not coherent.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
Just as a foolish person falsely takes a mirage to be water,
If you refute false grasping, the matter is also like this.
Grasped, grasper, and the act of grasping, refuted, refuter, and the act of refuting,
In this way, these six kinds of meanings are all existent dharmas.
If there is no grasping, the grasped, and the grasper,
Then there is no refutation, the refuted, and the refuter.
If there is no refutation, the refuted, and the refuter,
Then all dharmas are established, and their intrinsic nature is also established.
To these four lines of verse, I now reply to you with a verse, saying:
You speak the analogy of a mirage to illustrate the great meaning,
You listen, I can answer, like the analogy corresponds.
What does this verse clarify?
If you use this analogy of the mirage to illustrate the great meaning, you listen to my answer as it corresponds to the analogy.
The verse says:
If it has its own substance, it does not need to arise from causes and conditions;
If it needs causes and conditions, then it can be said to be empty.
What does this verse clarify?
If in the mirage one falsely grasps the substance of water that does not arise from causes and conditions, your analogy is appropriate.

The causes and conditions of the mirage are the inverted view, and the inverted view arises from not contemplating causes and conditions. In this way, it can be said to arise from causes and conditions.
If it arises from causes and conditions, its own substance is empty. This meaning is as explained above.
Moreover, there is another meaning, expressed in the verse:
If one grasps the reality of its own substance, who can turn it back?
The same is true for the rest, therefore I have no fault.
What does this verse clarify?
If the substance of water is grasped in mirage, how can anyone turn it back?
If there is a self-nature, it cannot be turned back, just as the heat of fire, the wetness of water, and the unobstructedness of space.
Seeing this can be turned back, in the same way one grasps the emptiness of self-nature. In this way, the meaning in the other dharmas should be understood in the same way.
In this way, just as grasping is unreal, the other five are also like this.
If you say those six dharmas exist, in this way it can be said that all dharmas are not empty, but the meaning is not consistent.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
Your reason is not established. How can there be a reason without substance?
If a dharma has no reason, how can it be said to be established?
If you establish without a reason that the self-nature of dharmas turns back,
I also establish without a reason that dharmas have a self-nature.
If there is a reason but no substance, this meaning is not consistent.
The dharma without substance in the world, then cannot be said to exist.
To this verse I now reply with a verse:
This statement without cause, the meaning has already been fully explained before,
The cause spoken of in the three times, is spoken of equally.
What meaning does this verse clarify?
This great meaning has already been explained before, this then is without cause, it should be known like this.
This kind of debate, the previous cause has already been explained to block the six kinds of turning back, that previous debate is now explained here.
Moreover, you spoke a verse, saying:
The previous negation of the later negation, like this is not appropriate,
The later negation if together with the previous, like this knows there is substance.
To this verse I now reply with a verse:
If speaking of the cause in the three times, the previous is like this equally,
Like this the cause in the three times, accords with the explanation of emptiness.
What meaning does this verse clarify?
If you say that the words refuting this reason apply to all three times, this has already been answered and should be understood accordingly.
Why is it so?
Because the reason is the same.
Just as refuting the three times is not appropriate, those words are also included in what is refuted.

If you think that even without what is refuted, refutation is still possible, I have already refuted it. This reason of the three times is consistent with the words of the one who speaks of emptiness.
Moreover, how is it that it has already been said?
As stated in the verse above:
I have nothing at all, therefore I do not refute,
In this way, you have no reason to unjustly accuse me.
If you further think that the refutation of the three times is established, seeing the reason before, seeing the reason after, and seeing the reason simultaneously.
The reason before is like a father with a son, the reason after is like a teacher with a disciple, and the simultaneous reason is like a lamp with light.
This I now say is not so.
The three kinds mentioned above each have three kinds of faults, which have been explained before.
Furthermore, in sequence, refuting your established thesis is lost, and so on, the negation of self-nature is established.
The verse says:
If a person believes in emptiness, they believe in everything;
If a person does not believe in emptiness, they do not believe in anything.
What does this verse clarify?
If a person believes in emptiness, they believe in all worldly and supramundane dharmas.
Why is it so?
If a person believes in emptiness, they believe in arising through the combination of causes and conditions;
If they believe in arising through the combination of causes and conditions, they believe in the Four Noble Truths;
If they believe in the Four Noble Truths, they believe in all the supreme realizations;
If a person is able to believe in all the supreme realizations, they believe in the Three Jewels, namely the Buddha, Dharma, and Sangha.
If they believe in arising through the combination of causes and conditions, they believe in the cause of dharmas and the result of dharmas;
If a person can believe in the causes and effects of dharmas, that person will then believe in the causes and effects of non-dharmas;

If a person can believe in the causes and effects of dharmas and non-dharmas, and believe in the causes and effects of non-dharmas, then they will believe in afflictions, the combination of afflictions, and the objects of afflictions.
That person will thus believe in all of these, as previously explained, they will then believe in good conduct and evil conduct;
If a person can believe in good conduct and evil conduct, that person will then believe in the dharmas of good and evil conduct;
If a person can believe in the dharmas of good and evil conduct, they will then know the means to transcend the three evil paths.
That person will thus be able to believe in all the dharmas of the world, such as these, which are immeasurable and cannot be fully explained.
The causes and conditions of emptiness itself are explained in the middle of the three and one,
I take refuge and pay homage to him, the unsurpassed great wisdom!
